title-group.article-title: Transverse vibration control of translating visco-elastically connected double-string-like continua

article-meta.aff: Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

author-notes.corresp: Mosaad A Foda, Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, King Saud University, PO Box 800, Riyadh 11421, Saudi Arabia Email: mfoda@ksu.edu.sa

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The aim of this work is to develop a direct and exact approach using the Green's functions to control the steady-state transverse vibration of an axially moving double-string system supported by two rollers (eyelets) at both ends. The two strings are similar and coupled by a viscoelastic layer of a Kelvin–Voigt type. The control is achieved by introducing suitable control forces (using actuators) or passive elements to be located at some chosen locations along the span between the eyelets. A scheme is proposed for evaluating the control forces and their locations to suppress the vibration of the system and correspondingly decrease the generated noise. The variation of the running speed and different end supports are taken into consideration.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: There is a long standing and extensive literature concerning axially moving systems.This is because they are frequently used in many engineering applications such as transmitting power, information or materials. Applications of these systems include moving threads, wires, transmission chain and belt drives, conveyor belts, band saws, steel strips, textiles fibers, magnetic tapes, paper sheets under processing, … etc. The study of these systems has been, and remains, a topic of great interest in many areas of physical sciences. The translating string and translating beam are the two most common models used to describe the dynamics of such systems. These basic models belong to the class of gyroscopic systems with infinite numbers of degrees-of-freedom manifested by Coriolis convective force resulted from moving relative references. These systems possess complex speed-depended modes and experience divergence instability at the critical speed where the fundamental natural frequency vanishes. Vibrations and noise associated with their motion create real problems in applications and degrade the system performance, in particular in high speed operations, and when lighter and higher quality materials are used. These vibrations can be due to support roller eccentricity, material non-uniformity, aero-dynamic disturbance, or manufacturing processes. It is thus desirable to suppress vibration and noise of the translating strings to improve their performances. The early research in this area includes the studies by Mahalingam (1957) and Archibald and Emslie (1958) who started to investigate the transverse oscillations of traveling strings. Since then, axially moving string-like continua have been subjects for study by many researchers due to their technological importance, see survey papers (Abrate, 1992; Wickert and Mote, 1988) for extensive lists of references. Various aspects of the dynamic response of axially moving string-like continua have received attention from many researchers (Chung and Tan, 1995; Zhu and Mote, 1995; Lee and Mote, 1996). Tan and Ying (2000) presented an active control scheme based on wave cancellation for an axially moving string with general boundary conditions. The problem is formulated in the frequency domain and two control forces are applied.

The effectiveness, robustness and stability of the control forces are demonstrated by simulation and verified by experiments on axially moving belt drive and chain drive systems. Yang et al. (2004) studied a two-span axially moving string subjected to varying tension and boundary disturbance. They used the Lyapunov method and semi-group theory to design a robust boundary adaptive control scheme for ensuring the vibration reduction in one span. Horssen and Ponomareva (2005) used the Laplace transformation method to construct the solution of the problem of moving string with constant speed. Li and Hou (2006) demonstrated that the oscillation of the moving string with finite deformation is exponentially stable when a linear boundary control negative feedback is applied.

Complex continuous systems, which are composed of two one-dimensional elastic solids attached by a visco-elastic layer, have theoretical and practical importance and have a wide application in mechanical, aeronautics and civil engineering. The double-string, double-beam and double-tube are examples of such systems. The dynamic responses of a double-string and double-beam systems have been considered by Oniszczuk (2000a,b,c, 2003a,b). These papers contain a good bibliography on the subject. Kukla (1994) and Vu et al. (2000) considered free and forced vibrations of a double-beam system while Zhang et al. (2008) studied the vibration and buckling of a double-beam system subjected to compressive axial load.

Rusin et al. (2011) studied the dynamic response of an elastically connected double-string complex system traversed by a force that moving with a constant velocity on the top string. They obtained a solution in a form of two infinite series but they managed to represent part of it in a closed, analytical form. By employing the dynamic Geen’s function, Foda and Alsaif (2009) annihilated the lateral vibration and slopes at chosen locations in a vibrating beam subjected to an external excitation.
More recently, Foda (2011) presented an exact, direct and simple method based on Green’s functions to suppress vibration of a moving belt modeled as a traveling string.

In the present work, the Hamilton principle is used to formulate the problem of an axially moving double-string system which runs across two roller supports with constant speed. The external excitation force that acted on the top string can be either concentrated at any point or distributed. The strings are identical, parallel and coupled by visco-elastic element that represented by Kelvin-Voigt model. The present work involves a change of variables to decouple the set of the two partial differential equations describing the system and then the solution is obtained by means of the dynamic Green’s function. Control forces will be applied at some arbitrary chosen locations along the span between the eyelets aiming at reducing the vibration level in most of the span by enforcing this region to be stationary or vibrating with an amplitude that is very small. Analysis will be performed to determine the control forces that are applied by actuators. In addition, the ability to suppress vibration by applying passive control means is also investigated. Numerical case studies are presented to verify the utility of the proposed scheme. The paper is split into four sections. Following this introduction, Section 2 develops the system equations of motions and the solution procedure. Numerical simulations and results are given in Section 3. Section 4 contains some conclusions.

sec.title: 2. Problem formulation
sec.p:
Consider a belt which is moving with an axial speed between two supporting rollers that are distance L apart as shown in Figure 1. The belt is formed from two similar and parallel strings that are coupled by visco-elastic element represented by Kelvin-Voigt model. The transverse deflection and variations in slope in each string are small, the effect of gravity is neglected, the mass of the belt per unit length is assumed to be constant, and the tension in the belt remains constant during motion. The system is assumed to be a line structure; which means that the lateral dimensions are much smaller compared to the longitudinal dimension (x-direction). In addition, it is assumed that the strings are possessing negligible resistance to bending compared to their resistance to axial deformation. As such, they idealized mathematically as a structure with vanishing bending stiffness. The transverse motion and axial effects in each string are coupled primarily through the axial tension. The Poisson effect will be neglected as well. The effect of air drag is neglected. It is assumed that the axial traveling speed is constant. Upon neglecting the axial vibration, the kinetic energy of the system can be written as (1)T=12∫0L∑j=1j=2ρA[∂wj(x,t)∂t+v∂wj(x,t)∂x]2dx where ρ is the mass per unit volume of the string material, A its cross-sectional area, v is the axial traveling speed and w1(x,t) and w2(x,t) are the transverse deflections of the top and bottom string at spatial distance x and at time t; respectively. Figure 1.
A schematic diagram of a harmonically excited axially moving double-string system.

After neglecting the effect of bending rigidity, the potential energy can be written as (2)U=12∫0L{T¯[∂w1(x,t)∂x]2+T¯[∂w2(x,t)∂x]2+12k0[w1(x,t) -w2(x,t)]2}dx+12k1[w1(0,t)-w2(0,t)]2 +12k2[w1(L,t)-w2(L,t)]2, where T¯ is the constant tension in the string, k0 is the stiffness modulus of the visco-elastic element and k1 and k2 are the stiffnesses of the supporting springs at x = 0 and x = L; respectively.

The equations of motion can now be derived by applying the extended Hamilton’s principle (Meirovitch, 2001) (3)∫t1t2(δT-δU+δWnc)dt=0, 0≤x≤L where δWnc denotes the virtual work done by the external forces (non-conservative forces) and can be expressed as (4)δWnc=∫0L[p1(x,t)δw1(x,t)+p2(x,t)δw2(x,t)]dx, where p1(x,t) represents the applied forces per unit length on the top string and represented by (5a)p1(x,t)=fext(x,t)+fd(x,t)+fc(t)δ(x-xc), while p2(x, t) is applied force on the bottom one and is given by (5b)p2(x,t)=-fd(x,t) where fext(x, t) is the applied external force, fc(t) is the applied control force that acts at x = xc, δ (.) is the spatial Dirac delta singularity function and fd(x, t) is the damping force exerted by the visco-elastic element and is given by (6)fd(x,t)=b[(∂w1(x,t)∂t-∂w2(x,t)∂t) +v(∂w1(x,t)∂x-∂w2(x,t)∂x)] with b is the damping constant of the visco-elastic element.

One lets the excitation force to be in the form (7)fext(x,t)=ReF0eiωtδ(x-xf), where the symbol Re means one takes the real part, i=-1 is the imaginary unit and F0 is the excitation force amplitude that applied at xf.

Substituting the expressions for T, U and δWnc in the standard form of Hamilton’s principle, (3), and then performing the usual variation, the following governing equations are derived (8)ρA[∂2w1(x,t)∂t2+2v∂2w1(x,t)∂x∂t+v·∂w1(x,t)∂x +v2∂2w1(x,t)∂x2]-T¯∂2w1(x,t)∂x2+k0[w1(x,t) -w2(x,t)]+b[∂w1(x,t)∂t-∂w2(x,t)∂t] +bv[∂w1(x,t)∂x-∂w2(x,t)∂x] =ReF0eiωtδ(x-xf)+fc(t)δ(x-xc),
(9)ρA[∂2w2(x,t)∂t2+2v∂2w2(x,t)∂x∂t+v·∂w2(x,t)∂x +v2∂2w2(x,t)∂x2]-T¯∂2w2(x,t)∂x2+k0[w2(x,t) -w1(x,t)]+b[∂w2(x,t)∂t-∂w1(x,t)∂t] +bv[∂w2(x,t)∂x-∂w1(x,t)∂x]=0,
Where v· denotes the rate of change of the traveling speed with time.
The corresponding boundary conditions are k1wj(x,t)-T¯∂wj(x,t)∂x=0,x=0k2wj(x,t)+T¯∂wj(x,t)∂x=0,x=Lj=1,2 <label>(10a,b)</label>
For the case in which the string is passing over fixed supports at both ends, the corresponding boundary conditions are wj(x,t) = 0 at x = 0 and at x = L.

Since the excitation is a sinusoidal function with frequency ω, then upon assuming that the traveling speed is constant (v· = 0), the sought solutions take the form (11)w1(x,t)=W1(x)eiωt,w2(x,t)=W2(x)eiωt,fc(t)=Fceiωt,

Whereby the symbol Re is suppressed. W1(x) and W2(x) represents the spatial complex deflection amplitude of the top and bottom string; respectively and Fc is the complex applied control force amplitude. The substitution of (11) into (8) and (9) leads to (12)(v2-c2)d2W1(x)dx2+2iωvdW1(x)dx-ω2W1(x) +k0+iωbρA[W1(x)-W2(x)]+bvρA[dW1(x)dx-dW2(x)dx] =F0ρAδ(x-xf)+FcρAδ(x-xc),
(13)(v2-c2)d2W2(x)dx2+2iωvdW2(x)dx-ω2W2(x) +k0+iωbρA[W2(x)-W1(x)]+bvρA[dW2(x)dx-dW1(x)dx] =0, where c=T¯/ρA represents the phase speed of the extensional wave, which is analogous to the speed of sound in fluids but its value in solids is quite high. For realistic physical situations, it is assumed that the traveling speed of the string v belongs to sub-critical speed (0 < v < c) since at a critical speed the fundamental natural frequency vanishes and divergence instability occurs (Mote, 1965). It is to be noted that for a belt in which the top and bottom strings are coupled by Winkler elastic elements with stiffness k0, the damping parameter b in (12) and (13) is set equal to zero which results in relatively simplified equations.

In the work to be followed, it is highly advantageous to work with non-dimensionalized quantities so that the presented numerical results are applicable for large combinations of system parameters and the analysis becomes more general. The adopted non-dimensional variables and coefficients are (14)x∧=x/L,ω∧=ωL/c,W∧j=Wj/L,k∧j=kjL/T¯,j=1,2v∧=v/c,k∧0=k0L2/T¯,η=ωb/k0F∧0=F0/T¯,F∧c=Fc/T¯,δ∧(x∧)=δ(x)/L

Therefore the non-dimensional governing equations for the system are (15)d2W∧1(x∧)dx∧2-λdW∧1(x∧)dx∧+qW1(x∧) -k∧0(1+iη)1-v∧2[W1(x)-W2(x)] -k∧0ηv∧ω∧(1-v∧2)[dW∧1(x∧)dx∧-dW2(x∧)dx∧] =-11-v∧2[F∧0δ∧(x∧-x∧f)+F∧cδ∧(x∧-x∧c)],
(16)d2W∧2(x∧)dx∧2-λdW∧2(x∧)dx∧+qW2(x∧) -k∧0(1+iη)1-v∧2[W2(x)-W1(x)] -k∧0ηv∧ω∧(1-v∧2)[dW2(x∧)dx∧-dW1(x∧)dx∧]=0 where (17)λ=2iω∧v∧1-v∧2, q=ω∧21-v∧2.

Before proceeding with the solutions of (15) and (16), the caret on the dimensionless quantities will be dropped for the sake of convenience and then the following new variables introduced (18a)Y1(x)=W1(x)+W2(x),
(18b)Y2(x)=W1(x)-W2(x).

Substituting (18a,b) into (15) and (16) the following governing equations are obtained (19)d2Y1(x)dx∧2-λ1dY1(x)dx∧+q1Y1(x) =-11-v2[F0δ(x-xf)+Fcδ(x-xc)],
(20)d2Y2(x)dx∧2-λ2dY2(x)dx∧+q2Y2(x) =-11-v2[F0δ(x-xf)+Fcδ(x-xc)], where (21)λ1=λ,q1=q,λ2=2v(iω+k0η/ω)1-v2,q2=ω2-2k0(1+iη)1-v2.

It is apparent that (19) describes the vibration of a traveling single string, while (20) represents a traveling single string resting on visco-elastic foundation with parameters 2k0 and 2η, where η is loss factor. From (18a,b), the transverse deflections of top and bottom strings are W1(x)=[Y1(x)+Y2(x)]/2,W2(x)=[Y1(x)-Y2(x)]/2.(22a,b)

To this end, Green's function is utilized to find the solutions of (19) and (20) because it simplifies the analytical procedure and yields exact solutions. Hence if Gj(x, u) is the dynamic Green's function, not yet defined, the solutions of (19) and (20) take the form (23)Yj(x)=∫01[F0δ(u-xf)+Fcδ(u-xc)]Gj(x,u)du,j=1,2

Green’s function Gj(x, y) is the solution of the differential equation (24)d2Gj(x,u)dx2-λjdGj(x,u)dx+qjGj(x,u)=-11-ν2δ(x-u). subjected to the associated boundary conditions for Wj(x) at x = 0 and at x = 1.

If the control force Fc depends on the transverse displacement and the velocity then it can be expressed as (25)Fc=(α1+iωα2)W1(xc)+α2vW1'(xc), where α1 and α2 are the displacement and velocity control gains respectively, where the prime denotes the derivative with respect x.
It is to be noted that, this control force can be implemented passively by a set of a translational spring, a damper and a rotational spring with constants −α1, −α2 and −α2v; respectively.

Substitution of (25) into (23) and performing the integration together with utilizing the properties of the Dirac delta function lead to the following exact solutions (26)Yj(x)=F0Gj(x,xf)+(α1+iωα2)W1(xc)Gj(x,xc) +α2vW1'(xc)Gj,u(x,xc),j=1,2 where Gj,u(x,u)=∂Gj(x,u)∂u.
The derivative of (26) with respect to x is (27)Yj'(x)=F0Gj,x(x,xf)+(α1+iωα2)W1(xc)Gj,x(x,xc) +α2vW1'(xc)Gj,ux(x,xc),j=1,2 where Gj,x(x,u)=∂Gj(x,u)∂x and Gj,ux(x,u)=∂Gj(x,u)∂u∂x.

Green's function is a type of function used to solve inhomogeneous differential equations subjected to boundary conditions. It can be very useful when dealing with linear systems, see book by Roach (1981). A knowledge of Green’s function of a vibrating body is all that needed in a vibration analysis of that body to specify its behavior completely. It is a symmetric function; therefore, it satisfies the Maxwell-Rayleigh reciprocity law. Green’s functions of strings with different types of supports at both ends are derived by Foda (2011) using the Laplace transform.

To this end, (26) and (27) is true at x = xc; therefore (28)Yj(xc)=F0Gj(xc,xf)+(α1+iωα2)W1(xc)Gj(xc,xc) +α2vW1'(xc)Gj,u(xc,xc).
(29)Yj'(xc)=F0Gj,x(xc,xf)+(α1+iωα2)W1(xc)Gj,x(xc,xc) +α2vW1'(xc)Gj,ux(xc,xc).

Utilizing (22a), (28) and (29) can be expressed in terms of W1(xc) and W1'(xc) (30)W1(xc)=F02[G1(xc,xf)+G2(xc,xf)] +12(α1+iωα2)W1(xc)[G1(xc,xc)+G2(xc,xc)] +12α2νW'(xc)[G1,u(xc,xc)+G2,u(xc,xc)]
(31)W1'(xc)=F02[G1x(xc,xf)+G2x(xc,xf)] +12(α1+iωα2)W1(xc)[G1x(xc,xc)+G2x(xc,xc)] +12α2νW'(xc)[G1,ux(xc,xc)+G2,ux(xc,xc)]

These simultaneous algebraic equations can be solved for W1(xc) and W1'(xc).The results are next substituted back into (26) to obtain the deflection Yi(x) at any point x on the string span. Finally, equations (22a,b) are utilized to find the transverse displacements W1(x) and W2(x) at any location x.

At this juncture, it is to be noted that if the excitation force is distributed over the top string or a part of it, the integration given in (23) can be performed over the domain of this force numerically and then replace the first term in (27) by the value of the integration result.

There are two cases which deserve special mention. The first case is the one where the belt is passing over fixed supports at both ends and the second case in which the belt is passing over supports that are elastically mounted at both ends.

sec.title: 2.1. String with fixed supports
sec.p: In this case, the Green’s function of the corresponding string is (Foda, 2011) (32)Gj(x,u)=11-v2{[epj1(1-u)-epj2(1-u)](pj1-pj2)[epj1-epj2][epj1x-epj2x] -H(x-u)(pj1-pj2)[epj1(x-u)-epj2(x-u)]},
Here H(u − x) is the unit step function and pj1 and pj2 are the roots of the characteristic equation (33)pj2-λjpj+qj=0, j=1,2

These roots are given by (34)pj1=(λj+Mj)/2,pj2=(λj-Mj)/2,Mj=(λj2-4qj)1/2, j=1,2 where λj and qj are given by (21). It is to be noted that when the loss factor η is neglected, the value of pj1 and pj2 are simplified to (35a)p11=iω1-v,p12=-iω1+v,
(35b)p21=iω1-v2[v+1-2k0(1-v2)/ω2],p22=iω1-v2[v-1-2k0(1-v2)/ω2]

To facilitate the subsequent analysis, we utilize the Maxwell-Rayleigh reciprocity law to rewrite (32) in the following form (36)Gj(x,u)={hj(u)[epj1x-epj2x],x≤uh¯j(u)[epj1(1-x)-epj2(1-x)]x>u where hj(u)=[epj1(1-u)-epj2(1-u)]/[(1-v2)(pj1-pj2)(epj1-epj2)],h¯j(u)=(epj1u-epj2u)/[(1-v2)(pj1-pj2)(epj1-epj2)].
If a constant control force Fc is applied at xc then (26) is simplified to (37)Yj(x)=F0Gj(x,xf)+FcGj(x,xc),j=1,2
Substituting (36) into (37) leads to (38)Yj(x)={[F0hj(xf)+Fchj(xc)]gj(x)x≤u[F0h¯j(xf)+Fch¯ji(xc)]g¯j(x)x>u j=1,2 where gj(x)=epj1x-epj2x,g¯j=epj1(1-x)-epj2(1-x)
It is apparent from (38) that the control force required to quench the vibration to the left of min (xf, xc) is given by (39)Fc=-F0[h1(xf)+h2(xf)]/[h1(xc)+h2(xc)],
While, the control force required to quench the vibration to the right of min (xf, xc) is given by (40)Fc=-F0[h¯1(xf)+h¯2(xf)]/[h¯1(xc)+h¯2(xc)]
In general Fc is a complex quantity and it can be applied actively by using external actuator, or by passive means.

sec.title: 2.2. String with elastic supports
sec.p: The Green’s function for an axially moving string that is passing over two end supports which are elastically mounted by two springs of stiffnesses k1 and k2 is given by (41)G(x,u)=-11-v2{H(x-u)(p1-p2)[ep1(x-u)-ep2(x-u)]-N(u)(p1-p2)D ×[(k1+p1-λ)ep1x-(k1+p2-λ)ep2x]}, where N(u)=(k2+p1)ep1(1-u)-(k2+p2)ep2(1-u),D=k2(k1-λ)[ep1-ep2]+(k1+k2-λ) ×[p1ep1-p2ep2]+[p12ep1-p22ep2]

A similar control law to that given by (39) and (40) can be derived. However; for this case, it is possible to apply the control force at x = 0 or at x = 1. This control input is commonly known as boundary control.

sec.title: 3. Results and discussions
sec.p: In this section, several numerical simulations are conducted to illustrate the utility and applicability of the proposed approach for quenching the vibration of a moving double-string system. In all the figures, the solid line corresponds to the deformed shape of the controlled top and bottom strings while the dashed line represents the deformed shape of the uncontrolled ones. The horizontal dotted line represents the configuration of the undeformed strings. The length of each string is assumed to be one meter, the string tension T¯ = 50 N, the mass per unit length ρA = 0.1 kg/m and the amplitude of the external force F0 = 2 N acts at xf = 0.5. In addition, k0 = 4 and the loss factor η = 0.5 unless otherwise stated.

Table 1 shows the first eight dimensionless natural frequencies of the system which is passing over fixed end supports, while those for a system passing over elastically mounted supports are given in Table 2. These frequencies correspond to the excitation frequencies at which the steady-state responses are infinite. Figure 2 depicts the steady-state dynamic responses of controlled and uncontrolled system which pass over fixed supports at both ends and moving with an axial speed v = 0.3. The top string is subjected to an external excitation force with frequency ω = 13.5 which is between the fourth and fifth natural frequencies, see Table 1. The control force that suppresses the vibration of the top string to the left of the applied external force according to (38) equals Fc = 0.0211 − 0.0482i. This control force is chosen to be applied near the right boundary at xc = 0.95. It is seen that the top string becomes motionless to the left of the applied external force, while the transverse deflection of the bottom string is suppressed significantly along its total span. Figure 2.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 13.5, Fc = 0.0211 − 0.0482i, xc = 0.95; o, control force location.
Table 1.
First eight dimensionless natural frequencies of the system passing over fixed end supports at various traveling speeds
ω1 ω2 ω3 ω4 ω5 ω6 ω7 ω8
v = 0 3.1416 4.2271 9.4247 9.8339 15.7089 15.9610 21.9915 22.1726
v = 0.3 2.8589 3.9410 8.5771 8.9910 14.2948 14.5461 20.0110 20.1932
v = 0.6 2.0105 3.0270 6.0315 6.4429 10.0525 10.3051 14.0748 14.2548
v = 0.9 0.5971 1.3703 1.7905 2.1743 2.9845 3.2296 4.1785 4.3561
Table 2.
First eight dimensionless natural frequencies of the system passing over elastically mounted end supports (k1 = k2 = 8) at various traveling speeds
ω1 ω2 ω3 ω4 ω5 ω6 ω7 ω8
v = 0 2.5294 3.7947 7.8706 8.3627 13.6277 13.9188 19.6239 19.8270
v = 0.3 2.3055 3.5517 4.6970 7.1974 7.6915 9.7913 10.1600 12.4535
v = 0.6 1.6283 2.7986 3.3417 4.0538 5.1384 5.6326 7.3646 8.8806
v = 0.9 0.4869 1.0102 1.3367 1.5627 2.1308 2.4891 2.7069 2.9986

Therefore; it is always possible to cancel the vibration of the top string to the left of the applied external force by applying a control force according to (38) at an arbitrary chosen location xc > xf. In Figure 3, the control force is plotted as a function of the control location xc for the system given in Figure 2. Considerable information can be drawn from this figure in terms of stability, optimality and type of control. Here optimality is based on the minimum control force requirement. It may be observed that there are optimal locations where the control force is minimal. The control force just near the nodes (the deflection amplitude W1(x) = 0) of the uncontrolled string is very large. As expected, if the control force is implemented at the mid-span, xc = 0.5, the control force has to be equal to F0. It is to be noted that the control force is positive in some regions and negative in others. Therefore the control can be achieved by passive means or active control has to be implemented. For the locations where the Im (Fc) = 0 and Re (Fc)/W1(xc) < 0, the control can be implemented passively by using a translational spring; which can be fixed at one end while the other end makes contact with the top string through a small roller. The flatness of the control force over the string span is a direct indication of robustness. Figure 3.
Variation of the required control force versus control force location for a system with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 13.5.

Figure 4 compares the maximum deflection amplitudes of the controlled and uncontrolled system in the controlled region (left of the excitation force) of the top string as a function of the excitation frequency ω for the system given in Figure 2. Figure 4.
Variation of the maximum amplitudes versus the excitation frequency for a system with fixed ends when v = 0.3, Fc = 0.0211 − 0.0482i, x c = 0.95.

The value of the control force and its location are held fixed. As shown when ω = 13.5, the vibration of the top string to the left of the excitation force is totally quenched. However; small variations of the excitation frequency from the tuned one will disturb the vibration suppression. The inset of Figure 5 shows the variation of the maximum deflection amplitudes in the controlled region versus the control force location xc. The values of the control force and the excitation frequency are held fixed. It is seen that if a small variation of xc from the chosen value (xc = .95) occurs, the deflection of the controlled top string is still substantially small compared to the uncontrolled deflection. It is to be noted that, if one is interested in quenching the vibration of the top string to the right of the applied external force, a control force which is the conjugate of that applied in Figure 2 should be implemented at xc = 0.05 as shown in Figure 6. Figure 5.
Variation of the maximum amplitudes versus control force location xc for a system with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 13.5, Fc = 0.0211 − 0.0482i.
Figure 6.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 13.5, Fc = 0.0211 + 0.0482i, xc = 0.05; o, control force location.

Figure 7 depicts the steady-state deflection responses when v = 0.3 and the excitation frequency ω = 14.27 which is in the vicinity of the fifth resonance frequency of the uncontrolled system (ω5 = 14.2948). The implemented control force Fc = 0.0594 − 0.0982i. This control force is chosen to be applied at xc = 0.95. The figure shows that the vibration along the entire top and bottom strings are quenched and the strings become motionless in the transverse direction. The vibrations reduction along the entire strings are achieved near resonance conditions because at resonance the transverse motion of the system is a simple spatial monochromatic waveform that can be cancelled by a single opposing wave that is created by an application of a control force. This effect is similar to that of the dynamic vibration absorber, which is used to quench the vibration of the harmonically excited single degree of freedom system. Figure 7.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 14.27, Fc = 0.0594 − 0.0982i, xc = 0.95; o, control force location.

Physically, the applied control force creates a transverse wave that is out of phase of the transverse wave generated by the external force. When these two waves are added together, the result is no vibration. Figure 8 presents a system similar to that given in Figure 7 but it is excited by a localized force that acts at xf = 0.75 with excitation frequency ω = 8.55 which is in the vicinity of the third natural frequency. The control force required to suppress the vibration Fc = −0.1129 − 0.0785 is chosen to be applied at xc = 0.95. Figure 9 compares the steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system when v = 0.3 and η = 0. The excitation frequency is ω = 20. A passive control force is applied to the system instead of an active control force. This passive control force is implemented by using a translational spring that is fixed at one end, while the other end touches the top string at location xc = 0.825. The stiffness of the spring k = 42.44. The same results can be obtained by attaching the aforementioned spring at any location that coincides with xc = 0.97, 0.68, 0.54, 0.47, 0.326, 0.175 or 0.036 as revealed by Figure 10, in which the variation of the spring stiffness versus its point of attachment xc is plotted. One particular consequence of the above results is that there are many different alternatives that can be used to suppress the vibration of the system. This is beneficial to practical implementation because one can choose the alternative that suits a certain application. Figure 11 shows the steady-state responses of controlled and uncontrolled system when the speed v = 0.6 and the excitation frequency ω = 6 which is close to the third natural frequency of the uncontrolled system (ω3 = 6.0315). The control force that suppresses the vibration along the top and bottom strings is Fc = −0.072 − 0.0505i chosen to be applied at xc = 0.05. Figure 12 depicts the steady-state responses of controlled and uncontrolled system when the speed v = 0.9, which is close to the critical speed. The excitation frequency ω = 2.98. The control force that suppresses the vibration is Fc = −0.0562 + 0.0039i at xc = 0.05. Figure 8.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system with fixed ends when v = 0.3, xf = 0.75, ω = 8.55, Fc = −0.1129 − 0.0785i, xc = 0.95; o, control force location.
Figure 9.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 20, η = 0, with attached translational spring at xc = 0.825, k = 42.44; o, spring location.
Figure 10.
Variation of the translation spring stiffness k versus the control location xc for a system with fixed ends when v = 0.3, ω = 20.
Figure 11.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system with fixed ends when v = 0.6, ω = 6, Fc = −0.0720 − 0.0505i, xc = 0.05; o, control force location.
Figure 12.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system with fixed ends when v = 0.9, ω = 2.98, Fc = − 0.0562 + 0.0039i, xc = 0.05; o, control force location.

Figure 13 illustrates the steady-state responses of controlled and uncontrolled system which is passing over an eyelet at each end. These eyelets are elastically supported by grounded springs of stiffness k1 = k2 = 8. The axial speed is v = 0.3 and the top string is subjected to an excitation force with frequency ω = 7.15 which is close to the fourth natural frequency of the system. The control force that suppresses the vibration of the top string in the region to the right of the excitation force is Fc = 0.0266 − 0.1079i, applied at the left support; xc = 0. It is seen that the vibration of the bottom string is totally quenched along its entire span and becomes motionless in the transverse direction. Figure 14 depicts a system similar to that given in Figure 13 but the axial speed v = 0.6 and the excitation frequency is ω = 5.12 which is in the vicinity of the fifth natural frequency of the uncontrolled system. The control force that suppresses the vibration of the top string to left of the excitation force is Fc = −0.1197 + 0.0739i applied at the right support; xc = 1. A final example is shown in Figure 15 which illustrates a system similar to that given in Figure 13 but the axial speed is close to a critical one; v = 0.9 and the excitation frequency is ω = 1.55. The control force that suppresses the vibration of the top string to the right of the excitation force is Fc = −0.0604 + 0.0888i implemented at the right support xc = 1. Figure 13.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and system with elastically mounted end supports, k1 = k2 = 8; when v = 0.3, ω = 7.15, Fc = 0.0266 − 0.1079; o, control force location.
Figure 14.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system with elastically mounted end supports, k1 = k2 = 8; when v = 0.6, ω = 5.12, Fc = −0.1197 + 0.0736i, xc = 1; o, control force location.
Figure 15.
Steady-state deflection responses of controlled and uncontrolled system with elastically mounted end supports, k1 = k2 = 8; when v = 0.9, ω = 1.55, Fc = −0.0604 + 0.0888i, xc = 1; o, control force location.

Before closing this section, a note should be added concerning the sensitivity of the dynamic response of the controlled system to small deviations in the system's parameters. It was found that small deviations in the value of the control force and/or its locations can cause small changes in the dynamic behavior of the controlled system compared with the case when the optimal values are selected. But small deviations in the excitation frequency (detuning) can cause considerable changes in the dynamic behavior of the controlled system and break down the vibration suppression. Therefore suppression is much more sensitive to the deviations in the excitation frequency than the deviations in the value of the control force or its location.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, the problem of achieving vibration suppression or confinement in an axially moving double-string subjected to an external excitation force has been examined analytically. This is achieved by adding a control force at a selected location on the top string. For a system with an external localized force that acts at any point on the top string, the deflection amplitude of the top string on either side of the external force can be suppressed by applying an appropriate active control force.

This control force also quenches the vibration of the bottom string along its entire span. Alternately, the control force can be applied passively by using a translational spring. A key feature of the present work is that the problem is formulated in terms of Green's functions. This method is exact and straightforward. It is free from the numerical inaccuracy when compared to the standard application of modal superposition technique.

def.p: derivative of the jth Green’s function w.r.t x
derivative of the jth Green’s function w.r.t u
spring stiffness of shock absorber at supports
rate of change of traveling speed
spatial transverse deflection of j th string
controlled deflection amplitude of j th string
uncontrolled deflection amplitude of j th string
(x, t): string transverse deflection of j th string
derivative of the Dirac delta function w.r.t its argument
